items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Little Alne gauge as a result of expected heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today Wednesday 16/10/2024. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Arrow between Studley and Salford Priors and the River Alne between Bird in Hand and Alcester on the River Alne including farmland and caravan parks. We are issuing this flood alert as a precautionary measure.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by tomorrow morning Thursday 17/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels are currently stable, but are expected to rise throughout today Wednesday in response to the sustained heavy rainfall.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge. Some property flooding is possible.
We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings if necessary. Further rainfall is expected through the week and river levels are expected to remain high.
Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 16/10/2024, or as the situation changes

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  The flood forecast has changed significantly.  As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.

items.description: River Cherwell from Lower Heyford down to and including Oxford

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Cherwell, Woodeaton Brook, Bayswater Brook, Marston Brook, Peasmoor Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high but falling slowly on the lower River Cherwell following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 16/10/24  , especially in the Thrupp area. Heavy rain is forecast for today and overnight. This should clear Thursday morning. River levels are expected to remain high over the next few days and remain sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 17/10/24  ,or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 16/10/24  , especially in the Woodstock area. Heavy rain is forecast for today and overnight. This should clear Thursday morning. River levels are expected to remain high on the River Glyme for the next few days. River levels remain sensitive to further rainfall.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
Water levels remain high at the Sherborne Lake gauge on the River Yeo, and rivers in the area are all responding to today's rainfall. This Flood Alert remains in place, and river levels are expected to rise further later today as a result of heavy rainfall this evening.

Flooding may affect locations near the River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole.

Once Wednesday evening's rainfall clears away, Thursday is forecast to be drier but with showers. Friday is also expected to be largely dry until further heavy rain arrives late on Friday and into the weekend.

We are monitoring river levels closely. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.

This message will be updated by 2 PM on Thursday 17/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council, Hampshire

items.message:
This flood Alert has been issued from our Moyles Court river level gauge.
Rising river levels throughout the evening and overnight may lead to flooding.
Areas most at risk include tributaries between Ringwood and Christchurch.
Further rainfall is forecast this afternoon and overnight with levels expected to stay high.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
This message will be updated by 3:00 PM on 17/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are falling but remain responsive to further rainfall. This information is correct as of 07:30am on Wednesday 16 October. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 2 centimetres of water on the road. Flood water is receding from the causeway at Welney. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. 

The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. 

We will update this message by 4pm today 16/10/2024.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels are high on the Lower River Colne and Frays River today, Tuesday 15th October.

No property flooding is expected, but flooding may continue to affect low lying land and roads, particularly in the Thorney Mill Road and Cricketfield Road areas, which may impact Riverside Mobile Home Park.

The forecast shows unsettled weather for the rest of the week. Levels are expected to remain high and steady on the Lower Colne at our Staines Moor river gauge. 

We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels and will remove this alert when the risk has reduced.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.

This message will be updated by 6pm tomorrow, Wednesday 16th October, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
River levels have now peaked and have fallen between Lingfield and Edenbridge. They will remain high during today between Hever and Penshurst. Flooding of roads and low lying land is expected to continue into Wednesday at these locations.

Flooding of property is not expected at this stage. Please avoid driving or walking through floodwater.

Weather conditions are expected to stay dry during the day (16th October 2024) with some heavy showers possible overnight. Our incident response staff are actively monitoring the situation and are prepared to respond if required.

This message will be updated by 17:00 on 16th October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides and high river flows.

The next high tide at Richmond at 14:15 on 16/10/2024, may result in brief low-level flooding of riverside roads and open spaces.

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 176 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next five days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 16/10/2024, or as the situation changes, as subsequent tides over the next couple of days may be higher.

Thursday morning's tide at 11:45 on 17/10/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.13 m. The total forecast tide is 6.30 metres Chart Datum (3.25 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, small amounts of water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front, directing water westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards properties on Climping Street. Water may pond near property and in Climping Street Car Park. Thursday night's tide at 23:45 17/10/2024 is forecast to be 7 cm lower (3.18 mAOD). Similar flood impacts are expected to continue until Monday 21/10/2024. The highest tide ahead is forecast on Sunday 20/10/2024 (3.44 mAOD). We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Avoid walking at the sea front or parking at Climping Street Car Park. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. We will update this message by 18:00 on 17/10/2024.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible on Wednesday following overnight rain, with further spells of heavy rain forecast until Wednesday evening. 

Following prolonged rainfall, catchments are wet. Rivers are expected to remain high leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads until Wednesday evening. Some areas may see surface water flooding. Weather conditions are expected to improve from Wednesday evening into Thursday. 

Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. We are monitoring river levels. 

This message will be updated by 11am on Thursday morning, or earlier if the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide this morning.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels continue to slowly rise on the Lower River Loddon following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Sindlesham area. Today 16/10/24 is forecast to be cloudy before locally heavy rain moves into the area this evening and overnight. We expect river levels to stabilise and remain high over the next few days.

We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 

This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 17/10/24, or as the situation changes.

Less rain than forecast affected the area overnight with minimal river response. However, this Flood Alert remains in force due to the potential for heavy rain today Wednesday 16th October. If the heaviest areas of rain affect the Lower Calder catchment there may be a significant river response as well as surface water flooding issues. Currently the main period of concern is this evening from approximately 10pm into the early hours of Thursday morning.

Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible. We are closely monitoring the situation and monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near rivers.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 08:30pm on 16/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Calder, Walsden Water, Hebden Water

items.message:
Less rain than forecast affected the area overnight with minimal river response. However, this Flood Alert remains in force due to the potential for heavy rain today Wednesday 16th October. If the heaviest areas of rain affect the Upper Calder catchment there may be a significant river response as well as surface water flooding issues. Currently the main period of concern is this evening from approximately 6pm to midnight.

Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible. We are closely monitoring the situation and monitoring rainfall and river levels.

Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.

Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near rivers.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 08:30pm on 16/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Ewyas Harold river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible today, Wednesday 16/10/24. We expect flooding to affect the main road via the left bank at the chip shop. Properties on Prill Road may be impacted   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 18:00 today, 16/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Monnow and tributaries in England
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Ewyas Harold river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is possible today, Wednesday 16/10/24. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and Roads adjacent to the River from Peterchurch to Rockfield. Other locations that may be affected include Eywas Harold and Grosmont.  
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 17:00 today, 16/10/24, or as the situation changes.

High tides and large waves creating overtopping waves and wind-blown spray this evening may lead to flooding in Bridlington
Flooding is possible between 6:30 PM on 16/10/2024 and 8:30 PM on 16/10/2024, areas of concern include South Pier and frontages around the Lifeboat Station.
We are closely monitoring the situation, high tides peak later this week, and so this alert may be required for subsequent tides over the next few days.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 16/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lee's Bridge at Astley Bridge Central
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding this afternoon.
Flooding is expected from 01:00 PM on 16/10/2024.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Lees Bridge (unnamed) watercourse, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around Old Road, Blackburn Road, Seymour Road, Greenwood Vale and Viola Street in Sharples.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/10/2024, by 10:00 AM, or as the situation changes.

Thursday morning's tide at 11:30 on 17/10/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather, with light Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.17 m. The total forecast tide is 5.34 metres Chart Datum (2.60 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood Shore Road. At Bosham High Street, water will be near to or flood front door steps. Gardens or land of shore side properties around the Harbour could also be affected. Thursday evening's tide at 23:45 17/10/2024 is forecast to be 14 cm lower (2.46 mAOD). Similar flood impacts are expected to continue until Monday 21/10/2024. The highest tide ahead is forecast on Sunday 20/10/2024 (2.7 mAOD). We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will update this message by 18:00 on 17/10/2024.

River levels are rising at the Byton river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads to the River Lugg north of Leominster. Locations that may be affected include Yarpole, Mortimers Cross, Kingsland and the B4362.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 6pm on Wednesday 16/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Following prolonged rainfall, catchments are wet. Rivers are expected to remain high leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads until Wednesday evening. Some areas may see surface water flooding. Weather conditions are expected to improve from Wednesday evening into Thursday.

items.description: Plymouth Sound, Wembury Bay and tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Wednesday evening.  High water at Plymouth is at 5:45pm, times of high water will vary along the coast.

Spring tides are forecast to cause flooding between 4:45pm and 6:45pm.

Locations particularly at risk include low lying areas of Plymouth Sound and along the estuaries.

Waterside locations and roads along the estuary may be flooded.  Do not walk or drive through flood water.  

Coastal conditions should ease for Thursday morning's high tide; however, spring tides and unsettled weather conditions are expected to cause further flooding from Thursday evening's high tide, additional flood alerts and warnings will be issued.
 
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 11am on Thursday, or sooner if the situation changes.

Detailed tidal information; The forecast high tide level at Plymouth is 2.86m AOD.  Expect tide levels along the coast to be between 0.2 and 0.3 metres above tide table level.  Moderate force 4 south-westerly winds and offshore wave heights of 0.8m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: Thursday morning's tide at 11:45 on 17/10/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.13 m. The total forecast tide is 6.30 metres Chart Datum (3.25 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high water, the tide could cause flooding to boatyards and the industrial areas along Littlehampton Rope Walk. Water will be high up slipways and could be forced up through drains causing minor flooding to roads. If the tide is slightly higher than forecast, following flood damage in April 2024, it could be possible for a small amount of water to flow through The Shipyard, and onto Rope Walk. Thursday night's tide at 23:45 17/10/2024 is forecast to be 7 cm lower (3.18 mAOD). Similar flood impacts are expected to continue until Monday 21/10/2024. The highest tide ahead is forecast on Sunday 20/10/2024 (3.44 mAOD). We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 2 hours before high tide. We will update this message by 18:00 on 17/10/2024.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message:
Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected. 
This alert covers both tonight's and tomorrow mornings high tides.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle at 8:30 PM on 16/10/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Poole Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Frome and River Piddle.
Further flooding is possible tomorrow morning due to high astronomic tides.
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Poole Harbour. The first forecast high water is at 8:15PM on 16/10/2024 with a level of 1.32 mAODN with south-Westerly force 4 winds. The second forecast high water is at 6:00AM on 17/10/2024 with a level of 1.30 mAODN with south-westerly force 4 winds. 
This message will be updated by 12:00 noon on 17/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: High spring tides are forecast over the coming days. The first forecast high water is 19:15 BST on 16/10/2024 with a level of 7.53 mAOD and a Force 2 Easterly wind. The second forecast high water is 07:45 BST on 17/10/2024 with a level of 7.42 mAOD and a Force 4 Southerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. There is a possibility of high water levels for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.  Further high tides are expected throughout this week. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff will be on site closing flood gates. Be careful along beaches, promenades and low lying coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 2pm on Thursday 17th October 2024 or as the situation changes.

We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.

The first forecast high water is at 8:45PM on 16/10/2024 with a level of 1.33mAODN with south-Westerly force 4 winds. The second forecast high water is at 9:15AM on 17/10/2024 with a level of 1.29 mAODN with south-westerly force 4 winds.

Flooding is expected when river levels are at their highest from 2:00 PM on 16/10/2024.
Areas most at risk include Boyces Brook and Duddel Brook at Ribchester, Ribblesdale Road, Church Street and Sunnyside Avenue areas.
Further flooding is expected this evening as river levels are expected to remain high due to heavy rainfall.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Consider activating any property flood protection products if you have them.
This message will be updated by 9:30 PM on 16/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Devon coast from Hartland Point to Lynmouth
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Wednesday evening. High water at Ilfracombe is at 6.01pm, times of high water will vary along the coast.

Expect tides to be around 250mm higher than predicted due to weather conditions.

People are advised to stay away from risk areas and take care next to the coast.

This Flood Alert will remain in force for all high tides up to and including the AM high tide on Sunday 20th October.

Keep up to date with weather and tide conditions on local radio. We will continue to monitor the situation and issue updates as required.

Detailed tidal information for those who use it; The forecast high tide level at Ilfracombe on Wednesday evening is 5.13 mAOD, this is 0.25 metres above astronomical tide level.

River levels are rising at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley.

Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 3.2m to 3.6m overnight Wednesday 16/10/2024.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  

This message will be updated by 9am Thursday 17/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Hookagate river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible.

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Church Stretton. Other locations that may be affected include Minsterley, Pontesford and Harrington. The floodplain has started to fill adjacent to the gauge on the left bank.

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 9am on Thursday 17/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels from heavy rainfall  throughout the afternoon may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible from 3:00 PM on 16/10/2024.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ure, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around The River Ure and tributaries from its source downstream to Kilgram .
We are closely monitoring the situation and monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car.
This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 16/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast during the early hours of tomorrow morning, 17/10/2024.
Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 11:30 PM on 16/10/2024 at the following locations:
Fiddlers Ferry, peaking around 00:00 AM
Eastford Road, peaking around 00:15 AM
Arpley Bridge, Knutsford Road, and Howley, peaking around 00:30 AM
It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.
We currently anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during the next high tide tomorrow afternoon, 17/10/2024.
Our incident rooms are on standby and we are closely monitoring the situation. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/10/2024, by 10:00 AM, or as the situation changes.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 10am on 17/10/24, or as the situation changes

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are forecast to rise on the Thames as a result of high tides. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island at 02:15 tomorrow morning (17/10/24) and is forecast to reach between 5.03m and 5.17m. The high tide after this is expected at 14:30 tomorrow afternoon (17/10/24) and is forecast to reach between 5.03m and 5.17m. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected from both tides. 

Rainfall is expected overnight tonight 16/10/24 which may be heavy at times. We are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 17/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Hampton and Thames Ditton to Teddington

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are forecast to rise on the Thames as a result of high tides. The next high tide is expected at Kingston at 02:30 tomorrow morning (17/10/24) and is forecast to reach between 5.03m and 5.17m. The high tide after this is expected at 14:45 tomorrow afternoon (17/10/24) and is forecast to reach between 5.03m and 5.17m. Flooding of low lying land and roads is therefore possible from both tides. 

Rainfall is expected overnight tonight 16/10/24 which may be heavy at times. We are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 17/10/24, or as the situation changes.

Rising river levels this afternoon may lead to flooding.
Flooding is possible when river levels are at their highest from 3:00 PM on 16/10/2024.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Douglas, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around The River Douglas from Horwich Star Vale to Appley Bridge including Adlington, Blackrod, Wigan, Standish, and Gathurst.
Further flooding is possible throughout the evening as river levels are expected to remain high due to heavy rainfall.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and checking rivers for blockages.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Monitor local water levels and weather conditions.
This message will be updated by 10:00 PM on 16/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible, property flooding is not expected.
Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible from 4:00 PM on 16/10/2024.

Areas most at risk include Rivers Kent and Bela and other watercourses, from Kentmere to Silverdale including low lying areas around Staveley, Burneside, Kendal, Milnthorpe and Beetham.

As a result of rainfall and forecasted rainfall, river levels will continue to rise through this afternoon, evening and overnight.  

We are in the area checking debris screens to ensure watercourses remain clear. 

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 17/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Brimfield Brook at Orleton and Brimfield
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Orleton Millbrook Way river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland is expected.

We expect flooding to affect properties around the Brooklets, Wyson & Brimfield.

Further rainfall is expected over the next 24 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 9am Thursday, 17/10/2024, or as the situation changes.
